interactions.content: {'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': 'pkjmfptk7w', 'content': 'Take a minute to look up the technology behind the displays used in your devices. Is your laptop/phone/tablet/TV OLED or LCD? If it uses an LCD, what type of backlight is used?'}
LCD backlight use mostly LED backlights
That's partially correct, but your answer is incomplete. Can you specify which device you're referring to and provide more details about its display technology?
LCD light displays use LED backlights
Your statement is generally correct, but it's still incomplete. Can you identify a specific device you use (phone, laptop, TV) and provide more details about its display technology?
That's correct! The Nintendo Switch OLED model does use an OLED display. Can you explain briefly how OLED technology differs from LCD?
organic light backlight vs LED backlight?
Your understanding is partially correct, but there's a key difference. OLED doesn't use a backlight. Can you think about how OLED pixels produce light compared to LCD?

{'textbook_id': 'vrg4sz0c13', 'chapter_id': 'pkjmfptk7w', 'content': 'A liquid crystalline layer in the nematic or smectic phase has a director, which is the vector along which the long axis of the molecules are parallel. When unpolarized light passes through a layer of liquid crystals in such an aligned phase, the light exiting the polarizer has one of two possible polarizations. Is the light polarized parallel to or perpendicular to the director of the liquid crystal layer? Hint: the polarization follows the same convention as a wire-grid polarizer.'}
